head.title: At Stake in Sierra Leone; A Colonial Legacy

hedline.hl1: At Stake in Sierra Leone; A Colonial Legacy

abstract.p: Frank Ulrich letter contends crisis in Sierra Leone is only one example of continuing civil wars, ethnic violence and brutal dictatorships in Africa that have their roots in 1950's and 1960's, when Europe's colonial powers 'all too hastily' granted independence to many African countries

block.p: The crisis in Sierra Leone (front page, May 9) is only one example of the continuing civil wars, ethnic violence and brutal dictatorships in Africa that have their roots in the 1950's and 60's, when Europe's colonial powers all too hastily granted independence to many African countries.

The crisis in Sierra Leone (front page, May 9) is only one example of the continuing civil wars, ethnic violence and brutal dictatorships in Africa that have their roots in the 1950's and 60's, when Europe's colonial powers all too hastily granted independence to many African countries.
If the transition from colonial rule to independence had been over a period of years, even a decade, these recurring problems might not have occurred or might have been minimized.

Furthermore, the neglect or willful destruction of much of these nations' infrastructure, making it virtually impossible to develop valuable natural resources, surely must have contributed to some of the appalling poverty in so many parts of Africa today. I doubt if some of these problems would have occurred if the transition from colonial rule had been smoother.
